page.title: 08Farming_sheep.
page.content: A small secondary benefit of keeping sheep is the income derived from the sale of their fleeces;but it is only a {small}benefit.The sheep are sheared each summer,and their fleeces wrapped inside out and tied with the twisted neck part,known as the 'bont'.In 1985, a fleece is worth only{40p}to the farmer. An average hill farm consists of two hundred acres,ten per cent of which will usually produce a hay crop,the rest,wherever possible,is grazed.The hay harvest is gathered slightly later here than elsewhere in Cheshire, usually in July.It is insufficient to maintain the winter flock,in fact most of the hay for the animals has to be bought in.Working sheepdogs are a common sight,helping the farmer to gather in part or all of his flock whenever necessary.
